Neuse, Friend, Scientist and Esteemed Colleague611617612201418102014612201414122014© Springer Science+Business Media New York 20142014Abstract

A two-fold interpenetrating two-dimensional CdII coordination polymer, [Cd(oba)(mmmb)·H2O]n (1) (mmmb = 5-methyl-1,3-bis(1-imidazolyl)benzene, H2oba = 4,4′-oxydibenzoic acid) has been prepared and characterized through IR, elemental analysis, thermal analysis and single-crystal X-ray diffraction. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis revealed that complex 1 is a two-fold interpenetrating (4,4)-connected network. These layers are linked by O–H⋯O and C–H⋯O hydrogen bonds to form a three dimensional supramolecular framework. The framework is reinforced by π–π interactions. In addition, complex 1 exhibits strong fluorescent emissions in the solid state at room temperature.

In recent years, the rational design and synthesis of coordination polymers not only owing to their intriguing topological architectures but also because of their potential applications in many fields, such as ion-exchange, heterogeneous catalysts, optical devices, magnets, and gas storage [1–6]. Generally, the structure of coordination polymers greatly depends on some factors such as temperature, the neutral ligands, the organic anions, the metal atoms, and so on [7, 8]. Among these factors, selecting appropriate organic ligand plays a vital role in the construction of coordination polymers with distinctive structures. The neutral imidazole-based bridging ligands as important build blocks are frequently used in constructing coordination polymers since imidazole groups have excellent coordination capabilities. To the best of our knowledge, the complexes containing 5-methyl-1,3-bis(1-imidazolyl)benzene (mmmb) regarded as a bis(imidazole) bridge ligand are very few [9]. On the other hand, 4,4′-oxydibenzoic acid (H2oba) as a symmetrical V-shaped aromatic polycarboxylic acid have be proven to be the good bridging ligands to construct novel coordination polymers [10–14]. However, coordination polymers constructed from H2oba and mmmb ligands have not been documented so far. Taking inspiration from the points mentioned above, we explored the self-assembly of CdII ion, H2oba, and mmmb under hydrothermal conditions, and obtained a novel 2D coordination polymer: [Cd(oba) (mmmb)·H2O]n (1). Herein, we report the synthesis, crystal structure, and physical properties of complex 1.

ExperimentalMaterials and Measurements

The mmmb ligand was prepared according to the previously reported procedure [9]. All other reagents and solvents used in the experiment were purchased from commercial sources and used without further purification. The C, H and N elemental analysis were performed on a Vario EL III elemental analyzer. Infrared spectra were recorded from KBr pellets in the range 4,000−400 cm−1 on a VECTOR 22 spectrometer. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were obtained on a Shimadzu XRD-6000 X-ray diffractometer with Cu Kα (λ = 1.5418 Å) radiation at room temperature. Fluorescent spectrum was recorded on a Fluoro Max-P spectrophotometer. Thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed on a Perkin-Elmer Pyris 1 TGA analyzer from 25 to 800 °C with a heating rate of 20 °C min−1 under nitrogen.

Synthesis of the Complex [Cd(oba)(mmmb)·H<sub>2</sub>O]<sub>n</sub> (<bold>1</bold>)

A mixture of Cd(NO3)2·6H2O (0.0346 g, 0.100 mmol), H2oba (0.0258 g, 0.100 mmol), mmmb (0.0224 g, 0.100 mmol), NaOH (0.008 g, 0.2 mmol) in H2O (10 mL) was sealed in a 16 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel container and heated at 150 °C for 72 h. After cooling to room temperature, colourless block crystals were collected by filtration and washed by water and ethanol several times (yield 23.2 %, based on Cd). Elemental analysis for C27H22CdN4O6 (Mr = 610.89): C 53.08, H 3.63, N 9.17 %; found: C 53.22, H 3.64, N 9.19 %. IR (KBr, cm−1) 3601 (s), 2375 (w), 1645 (s), 1421 (s), 1123 (m), 981 (m), 742 (m), 652 (s).

X-ray Crystallographic Study of Complex

Crystallographic diffraction data for complex 1 was recorded on a Siemens (Bruker) SMART CCD diffractometer using monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 296 K. Absorption correction was applied using multi-scan technique. The structure was solved by direct methods and refined with full-matrix least-squares technique (SHELXTL-97) [15]. H atoms bonded to C atoms were placed in calculated positions and treated using a riding-model approximation, with C–H = 0.93 (imidazole and benzene) and with Uiso(H) = 1.2Ueq(C), or 0.96 Å (methyl) and with Uiso(H) = 1.5Ueq(C). Water H atoms were located in difference Fourier maps and refined as riding, with Uiso(H) = 1.5Ueq(O). The crystal data and structural refinement parameters of complex 1 are given in Table 1. Selected bond lengths and angles are given in Table 2.

Results and DiscussionDescription of Crystal Structure

X-ray crystallography reveals that the asymmetric unit of complex 1 consists of two crystallographically independent divalent cadmium ions (Cd1 and Cd2), two fully deprotonated oba ligands (oba-A, O1–O5/C1–C14; oba-B, O6–O10/C28–C41), two mmmb ligands (mmmb-A, N1–N4/C15–C27; mmmb-B, N5–N8/C42–C54), and two aqua ligands. As shown in Fig. 1, both Cd1 and Cd2 atoms are coordinated by two nitrogen atoms from two different mmmb ligands and four oxygen atoms from two different OBA2− ligands to give distorted CdN2O4 octahedron geometries. The bond distances and angles around CdII ions are 2.278(2)–2.326(2) Å for Cd–N, 2.225(2)–2.502(2) Å for Cd–O, 103.12(9)–103.30(9) Å for N–Cd–N, 86.62(8)–151.72(8) Å for N–Cd–O, and 54.50(7)–158.16(8) Å for O–Cd–O, which are similar to other Cd-based complexes [16, 17].

In complex 1, the dihedral angle between the two benzene rings is 69.5(1)° for oba-A ligand, while the corresponding angle in oba-B ligand is 85.8(3)°. Adjacent Cd1 atoms are linked through the oba-A ligands to form [Cd(oba-A)]n 1D chains (chain-A) with a Cd⋯Cd distance of 14.5232(14) Å. Similarly, neighboring Cd2 atoms are conjoined via oba-B ligands to form crystallographically distinct [Cd(oba-B)]n 1D chains (chain-B) with a Cd⋯Cd distance of 14.5232(14) Å.

Chain-A 1D motifs connect into a 2D [Cd(oba-A)(mmmb-A)]n layered motif (layer-A) through tethering mmmb-A ligands, with a Cd⋯Cd through mmmb-A distance of 11.8715(11) Å. In layer-A, the dihedral angle between the two imidazole rings is 36.2(1) Å for the mmmb-A ligands. The slab pattern of layer-A can be represented as a (4,4) rectangular grid motif. As determined by through-space Cd⋯Cd distances, the apertures within the grid measure 17.6707(13) × 19.7853(14) Å. In turn, adjacent chain-B 1D patterns are further linked into similar 2D (4,4) grid coordination polymer layers by mmmb-B ligands with the Cd⋯Cd through mmmb-B distance of 11.8715(11) Å (Fig. 2). In layer-B, the dihedral angle between the two imidazole rings is 29.3(2)° for the mmmb-B ligands. The apertures bracketed by the oba-B and mmmb-B ligands measure 17.6707(13) by 19.7853(14) Å with Cd⋯Cd⋯Cd angles of 83.41(2)º and 96.59(2)º. Crystallographically distinct layer-A and layer-B motifs then interpenetrate with each other and lead to form an interesting two-fold interpenetrating structure because of the large cage in complex 1 (Fig. 3).

The crystal structure of complex 1 is further strengthened through hydrogen bonding interactions between lattice water molecules and carboxylate oxygen atoms (O11⋯O6 = 2.758(4) Å, O12⋯O5 = 2.830(4) Å and O11⋯O3 = 3.294(4) Å), as well as between lattice water molecules (O11⋯O12 = 2.884(6) Å) (Fig. 4). In addition, there are numerous nonclassical C–H⋯O hydrogen bonds in the structure, with C–H⋯O angles in the range 121.4º–171.0º, and C⋯O and H⋯O distances in the ranges 3.117(4)–3.522(4) and 2.37–2.58 Å respectively, generating an extensive three dimensional hydrogen-bond network. This framework is reinforced by π–π interactions between adjacent imidazole rings, with a Cg1⋯Cg2iii separation of 3.616(2) Å [Cg1 and Cg2 are the centroids of the N1–N2/C15–C17 and N5–N6/C42–C44 rings, respectively; symmetry code: (iii) −x + 1, −y + 1, −z + 1], π–π interactions between the benzene rings, with a Cg3⋯Cg3v separation of 3.5366(18) Å [Cg3 is the centroids of the C45–C50 rings, symmetry code: (v) −x + 1, −y + 2, −z + 1] and π–π interactions between the benzene rings, with a Cg4⋯Cg5vi separation of 3.7264(18) Å [Cg4 and Cg5 are the centroids of are the centroids of the C2–C7 and C29–C34 rings; symmetry code: (vi) −x + 1, −y + 1, −z] (Fig. 5). Approximately 5.6 % of the crystal volume is occupied by the solvent molecules, with a volume of 135.7 Å3 in each unit cell (2,419.1 Å3) based on a PLATON calculation.

PXRD Patterns and Thermal Analysis

The phase purity of the as-synthesized complex 1 was testified by X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) experiment. The peak positions of the experimental and simulated XRPD patterns are in good agreement with each other, which demonstrates that complex 1 has been obtained successfully as a pure crystalline phase (Fig. 6). The differences in intensity may be owing to the preferred orientation of the powder samples.

To verify the thermal stability of complex 1, TGA was carried out. As shown in Fig. 7, complex 1 undergoes dehydration in the range of 90–114 °C (obsd. 3.19 %, calcd. 2.95 %), and the decomposition of the organic ligand is observed from 198 to 715 °C. The remaining weight corresponds to the formation of CdO (obsd. 21.86 %, calcd. 21.02 %).

Photoluminescence Properties

Due to the excellent fluorescent properties of d10 metal complexes, the solid-state photoluminescent property of complex 1 has been investigated at room temperature [18, 19]. The free ligand H2OBA displays photoluminescence with the emission maximum at 319 nm (λex = 276 nm), which are probably attributed to the π*–n or π*–π transitions as previously reported [11]. Irradiation of complex 1 with ultraviolet light (λex = 320 nm) in the solid state resulted in a relatively emission band centered on ~381 nm (Fig. 8). Because the CdII ion is difficult to oxidize or to reduce due to the d10 configuration, the emissions are neither metal-to-ligand charge transfer nor ligand-to-metal charge transfer [20, 21]. As a result, the emissive behavior of complex 1 can be attributed to ligand-centered electronic transitions.

Conclusions

In summary, one coordination polymer based on mmmb and H2oba has been prepared and characterized through IR, elemental analysis, thermal analysis and single-crystal X-ray diffraction. The crystal structure of complex 1 shows a two-fold interpenetrating (4,4)-connected network. In addition, complex 1 exhibits strong fluorescent emissions in the solid state at room temperature.

Supplementary Material

Crystallographic data for the structural analysis have been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Center, and CCDC No. 1035491 for complex 1. Copies of the data can be obtained free of charge on application to the Director, CCDC, 12 Union Road, Cambridge, CB2 1EZ, UK (Fax: +44–1223–336033; e-mail: deposit@ccdc.cam.ac.uk or http://www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk).

In addition, there are numerous nonclassical C-H⋯O hydrogen bonds in the structure, with C-H⋯O angles in the range 121.4º-171.0º, and C⋯O and H⋯O distances in the ranges 3.117(4)-3.522(4) and 2.37-2.58 Å respectively, generating an extensive three dimensional hydrogen-bond network. This framework is reinforced by π-π interactions between adjacent imidazole rings, with a Cg1⋯Cg2iii separation of 3.616(2) Å [Cg1 and Cg2 are the centroids of the N1-N2/C15-C17 and N5-N6/C42-C44 rings, respectively; symmetry code: (iii) -x + 1, -y + 1, -z + 1], π-π interactions between the benzene rings, with a Cg3⋯Cg3v separation of 3.5366(18) Å [Cg3 is the centroids of the C45-C50 rings, symmetry code: (v) -x + 1, -y + 2, -z + 1] and π-π interactions between the benzene rings, with a Cg4⋯Cg5vi separation of 3.7264(18) Å [Cg4 and Cg5 are the centroids of are the centroids of the C2-C7 and C29-C34 rings; symmetry code: (vi) -x + 1, -y + 1, -z] (Fig. 5). Approximately 5.6 % of the crystal volume is occupied by the solvent molecules, with a volume of 135.7 Å3 in each unit cell (2,419.1 Å3) based on a PLATON calculation.PXRD Patterns and Thermal AnalysisThe phase purity of the as-synthesized complex 1 was testified by X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) experiment. The peak positions of the experimental and simulated XRPD patterns are in good agreement with each other, which demonstrates that complex 1 has been obtained successfully as a pure crystalline phase (Fig. 6). The differences in intensity may be owing to the preferred orientation of the powder samples.To verify the thermal stability of complex 1, TGA was carried out. As shown in Fig. 7, complex 1 undergoes dehydration in the range of 90-114 °C (obsd. 3.19 %, calcd. 2.95 %), and the decomposition of the organic ligand is observed from 198 to 715 °C. The remaining weight corresponds to the formation of CdO (obsd. 21.86 %, calcd. 21.02 %).Photoluminescence PropertiesDue to the excellent fluorescent properties of d10 metal complexes, the solid-state photoluminescent property of complex 1 has been investigated at room temperature [18, 19]. The free ligand H2OBA displays photoluminescence with the emission maximum at 319 nm (λex = 276 nm), which are probably attributed to the π*-n or π*-π transitions as previously reported [11]. Irradiation of complex 1 with ultraviolet light (λex = 320 nm) in the solid state resulted in a relatively emission band centered on ~381 nm (Fig. 8). Because the CdII ion is difficult to oxidize or to reduce due to the d10 configuration, the emissions are neither metal-to-ligand charge transfer nor ligand-to-metal charge transfer [20, 21]. As a result, the emissive behavior of complex 1 can be attributed to ligand-centered electronic transitions.ConclusionsIn summary, one coordination polymer based on mmmb and H2oba has been prepared and characterized through IR, elemental analysis, thermal analysis and single-crystal X-ray diffraction. The crystal structure of complex 1 shows a two-fold interpenetrating (4,4)-connected network. In addition, complex 1 exhibits strong fluorescent emissions in the solid state at room temperature.Supplementary MaterialCrystallographic data for the structural analysis have been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Center, and CCDC No. 1035491 for complex 1. elements.content: A two-fold interpenetrating two-dimensional CdII coordination polymer, [Cd(oba)(mmmb)·H2O]n (1) (mmmb = 5-methyl-1,3-bis(1-imidazolyl)benzene, H2oba = 4,4′-oxydibenzoic acid) has been prepared and characterized through IR, elemental analysis, thermal analysis and single-crystal X-ray diffraction. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis revealed that complex 1 is a two-fold interpenetrating (4,4)-connected network. These layers are linked by O–H⋯O and C–H⋯O hydrogen bonds to form a three dimensional supramolecular framework. The framework is reinforced by π–π interactions. In addition, complex 1 exhibits strong fluorescent emissions in the solid state at room temperature.
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

A two-fold interpenetrating two-dimensional CdII coordination polymer, [Cd(oba)(mmmb)⋅H2O]n (1) (mmmb = 5-methyl-1,3-bis(1-imidazolyl)benzene, H2oba = 4,4'-oxydibenzoic acid) has been prepared and characterized through IR, elemental analysis, thermal analysis and single-crystal X-ray diffraction. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis revealed that complex 1 is a two-fold interpenetrating (4,4)-connected network. These layers are linked by O-H⋯O and C-H⋯O hydrogen bonds to form a three dimensional supramolecular framework. The framework is reinforced by π-π interactions. In addition, complex 1 exhibits strong fluorescent emissions in the solid state at room temperature.

elements.content: In recent years, the rational design and synthesis of coordination polymers not only owing to their intriguing topological architectures but also because of their potential applications in many fields, such as ion-exchange, heterogeneous catalysts, optical devices, magnets, and gas storage [1–6]. Generally, the structure of coordination polymers greatly depends on some factors such as temperature, the neutral ligands, the organic anions, the metal atoms, and so on [7, 8]. Among these factors, selecting appropriate organic ligand plays a vital role in the construction of coordination polymers with distinctive structures. The neutral imidazole-based bridging ligands as important build blocks are frequently used in constructing coordination polymers since imidazole groups have excellent coordination capabilities. To the best of our knowledge, the complexes containing 5-methyl-1,3-bis(1-imidazolyl)benzene (mmmb) regarded as a bis(imidazole) bridge ligand are very few [9]. On the other hand, 4,4′-oxydibenzoic acid (H2oba) as a symmetrical V-shaped aromatic polycarboxylic acid have be proven to be the good bridging ligands to construct novel coordination polymers [10–14]. However, coordination polymers constructed from H2oba and mmmb ligands have not been documented so far. Taking inspiration from the points mentioned above, we explored the self-assembly of CdII ion, H2oba, and mmmb under hydrothermal conditions, and obtained a novel 2D coordination polymer: [Cd(oba) (mmmb)·H2O]n (1). Herein, we report the synthesis, crystal structure, and physical properties of complex 1.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

In recent years, the rational design and synthesis of coordination polymers not only owing to their intriguing topological architectures but also because of their potential applications in many fields, such as ion-exchange, heterogeneous catalysts, optical devices, magnets, and gas storage [1-6]. Generally, the structure of coordination polymers greatly depends on some factors such as temperature, the neutral ligands, the organic anions, the metal atoms, and so on [7, 8]. Among these factors, selecting appropriate organic ligand plays a vital role in the construction of coordination polymers with distinctive structures. The neutral imidazole-based bridging ligands as important build blocks are frequently used in constructing coordination polymers since imidazole groups have excellent coordination capabilities. To the best of our knowledge, the complexes containing 5-methyl-1,3-bis(1-imidazolyl)benzene (mmmb) regarded as a bis(imidazole) bridge ligand are very few [9]. On the other hand, 4,4'-oxydibenzoic acid (H2oba) as a symmetrical V-shaped aromatic polycarboxylic acid have be proven to be the good bridging ligands to construct novel coordination polymers [10-14]. However, coordination polymers constructed from H2oba and mmmb ligands have not been documented so far. Taking inspiration from the points mentioned above, we explored the self-assembly of CdII ion, H2oba, and mmmb under hydrothermal conditions, and obtained a novel 2D coordination polymer: [Cd(oba) (mmmb)⋅H2O]n (1). Herein, we report the synthesis, crystal structure, and physical properties of complex 1.

elements.content: The mmmb ligand was prepared according to the previously reported procedure [9]. All other reagents and solvents used in the experiment were purchased from commercial sources and used without further purification. The C, H and N elemental analysis were performed on a Vario EL III elemental analyzer. Infrared spectra were recorded from KBr pellets in the range 4,000−400 cm−1 on a VECTOR 22 spectrometer. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were obtained on a Shimadzu XRD-6000 X-ray diffractometer with Cu Kα (λ = 1.5418 Å) radiation at room temperature. Fluorescent spectrum was recorded on a Fluoro Max-P spectrophotometer. Thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed on a Perkin-Elmer Pyris 1 TGA analyzer from 25 to 800 °C with a heating rate of 20 °C min−1 under nitrogen.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental

Materials and Measurements

The mmmb ligand was prepared according to the previously reported procedure [9]. All other reagents and solvents used in the experiment were purchased from commercial sources and used without further purification. The C, H and N elemental analysis were performed on a Vario EL III elemental analyzer. Infrared spectra were recorded from KBr pellets in the range 4,000-400 cm-1 on a VECTOR 22 spectrometer. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were obtained on a Shimadzu XRD-6000 X-ray diffractometer with Cu Kα (λ = 1.5418 Å) radiation at room temperature. Fluorescent spectrum was recorded on a Fluoro Max-P spectrophotometer. Thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed on a Perkin-Elmer Pyris 1 TGA analyzer from 25 to 800 °C with a heating rate of 20 °C min-1 under nitrogen.

elements.content: A mixture of Cd(NO3)2·6H2O (0.0346 g, 0.100 mmol), H2oba (0.0258 g, 0.100 mmol), mmmb (0.0224 g, 0.100 mmol), NaOH (0.008 g, 0.2 mmol) in H2O (10 mL) was sealed in a 16 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel container and heated at 150 °C for 72 h. After cooling to room temperature, colourless block crystals were collected by filtration and washed by water and ethanol several times (yield 23.2 %, based on Cd). Elemental analysis for C27H22CdN4O6 (Mr = 610.89): C 53.08, H 3.63, N 9.17 %; found: C 53.22, H 3.64, N 9.19 %. IR (KBr, cm−1) 3601 (s), 2375 (w), 1645 (s), 1421 (s), 1123 (m), 981 (m), 742 (m), 652 (s).

Synthesis of the Complex [Cd(oba)(mmmb)⋅H2O]n (1)

A mixture of Cd(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.0346 g, 0.100 mmol), H2oba (0.0258 g, 0.100 mmol), mmmb (0.0224 g, 0.100 mmol), NaOH (0.008 g, 0.2 mmol) in H2O (10 mL) was sealed in a 16 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel container and heated at 150 °C for 72 h. After cooling to room temperature, colourless block crystals were collected by filtration and washed by water and ethanol several times (yield 23.2 %, based on Cd). Elemental analysis for C27H22CdN4O6 (Mr = 610.89): C 53.08, H 3.63, N 9.17 %; found: C 53.22, H 3.64, N 9.19 %. IR (KBr, cm-1) 3601 (s), 2375 (w), 1645 (s), 1421 (s), 1123 (m), 981 (m), 742 (m), 652 (s).

elements.content: Crystallographic diffraction data for complex 1 was recorded on a Siemens (Bruker) SMART CCD diffractometer using monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 296 K. Absorption correction was applied using multi-scan technique. The structure was solved by direct methods and refined with full-matrix least-squares technique (SHELXTL-97) [15]. H atoms bonded to C atoms were placed in calculated positions and treated using a riding-model approximation, with C–H = 0.93 (imidazole and benzene) and with Uiso(H) = 1.2Ueq(C), or 0.96 Å (methyl) and with Uiso(H) = 1.5Ueq(C). Water H atoms were located in difference Fourier maps and refined as riding, with Uiso(H) = 1.5Ueq(O). The crystal data and structural refinement parameters of complex 1 are given in Table 1. Selected bond lengths and angles are given in Table 2.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallographic Study of Complex

Crystallographic diffraction data for complex 1 was recorded on a Siemens (Bruker) SMART CCD diffractometer using monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 296 K. Absorption correction was applied using multi-scan technique. The structure was solved by direct methods and refined with full-matrix least-squares technique (SHELXTL-97) [15]. H atoms bonded to C atoms were placed in calculated positions and treated using a riding-model approximation, with C-H = 0.93 (imidazole and benzene) and with Uiso(H) = 1.2Ueq(C), or 0.96 Å (methyl) and with Uiso(H) = 1.5Ueq(C). Water H atoms were located in difference Fourier maps and refined as riding, with Uiso(H) = 1.5Ueq(O). The crystal data and structural refinement parameters of complex 1 are given in Table 1. Selected bond lengths and angles are given in Table 2.

X-ray crystallography reveals that the asymmetric unit of complex 1 consists of two crystallographically independent divalent cadmium ions (Cd1 and Cd2), two fully deprotonated oba ligands (oba-A, O1–O5/C1–C14; oba-B, O6–O10/C28–C41), two mmmb ligands (mmmb-A, N1–N4/C15–C27; mmmb-B, N5–N8/C42–C54), and two aqua ligands. As shown in Fig. 1, both Cd1 and Cd2 atoms are coordinated by two nitrogen atoms from two different mmmb ligands and four oxygen atoms from two different OBA2− ligands to give distorted CdN2O4 octahedron geometries. The bond distances and angles around CdII ions are 2.278(2)–2.326(2) Å for Cd–N, 2.225(2)–2.502(2) Å for Cd–O, 103.12(9)–103.30(9) Å for N–Cd–N, 86.62(8)–151.72(8) Å for N–Cd–O, and 54.50(7)–158.16(8) Å for O–Cd–O, which are similar to other Cd-based complexes [16, 17].
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Description of Crystal Structure

X-ray crystallography reveals that the asymmetric unit of complex 1 consists of two crystallographically independent divalent cadmium ions (Cd1 and Cd2), two fully deprotonated oba ligands (oba-A, O1-O5/C1-C14; oba-B, O6-O10/C28-C41), two mmmb ligands (mmmb-A, N1-N4/C15-C27; mmmb-B, N5-N8/C42-C54), and two aqua ligands. As shown in Fig. 1, both Cd1 and Cd2 atoms are coordinated by two nitrogen atoms from two different mmmb ligands and four oxygen atoms from two different OBA2- ligands to give distorted CdN2O4 octahedron geometries. The bond distances and angles around CdII ions are 2.278(2)-2.326(2) Å for Cd-N, 2.225(2)-2.502(2) Å for Cd-O, 103.12(9)-103.30(9) Å for N-Cd-N, 86.62(8)-151.72(8) Å for N-Cd-O, and 54.50(7)-158.16(8) Å for O-Cd-O, which are similar to other Cd-based complexes [16, 17].

elements.content: In complex 1, the dihedral angle between the two benzene rings is 69.5(1)° for oba-A ligand, while the corresponding angle in oba-B ligand is 85.8(3)°. Adjacent Cd1 atoms are linked through the oba-A ligands to form [Cd(oba-A)]n 1D chains (chain-A) with a Cd⋯Cd distance of 14.5232(14) Å. Similarly, neighboring Cd2 atoms are conjoined via oba-B ligands to form crystallographically distinct [Cd(oba-B)]n 1D chains (chain-B) with a Cd⋯Cd distance of 14.5232(14) Å.

Adjacent Cd1 atoms are linked through the oba-A ligands to form [Cd(oba-A)]n 1D chains (chain-A) with a Cd⋯Cd distance of 14.5232(14) Å. Similarly, neighboring Cd2 atoms are conjoined via oba-B ligands to form crystallographically distinct [Cd(oba-B)]n 1D chains (chain-B) with a Cd⋯Cd distance of 14.5232(14) Å.

elements.content: Chain-A 1D motifs connect into a 2D [Cd(oba-A)(mmmb-A)]n layered motif (layer-A) through tethering mmmb-A ligands, with a Cd⋯Cd through mmmb-A distance of 11.8715(11) Å. In layer-A, the dihedral angle between the two imidazole rings is 36.2(1) Å for the mmmb-A ligands. The slab pattern of layer-A can be represented as a (4,4) rectangular grid motif. As determined by through-space Cd⋯Cd distances, the apertures within the grid measure 17.6707(13) × 19.7853(14) Å. In turn, adjacent chain-B 1D patterns are further linked into similar 2D (4,4) grid coordination polymer layers by mmmb-B ligands with the Cd⋯Cd through mmmb-B distance of 11.8715(11) Å (Fig. 2). In layer-B, the dihedral angle between the two imidazole rings is 29.3(2)° for the mmmb-B ligands. The apertures bracketed by the oba-B and mmmb-B ligands measure 17.6707(13) by 19.7853(14) Å with Cd⋯Cd⋯Cd angles of 83.41(2)º and 96.59(2)º. Crystallographically distinct layer-A and layer-B motifs then interpenetrate with each other and lead to form an interesting two-fold interpenetrating structure because of the large cage in complex 1 (Fig. 3).

In layer-A, the dihedral angle between the two imidazole rings is 36.2(1) Å for the mmmb-A ligands. The slab pattern of layer-A can be represented as a (4,4) rectangular grid motif. As determined by through-space Cd⋯Cd distances, the apertures within the grid measure 17.6707(13) × 19.7853(14) Å. In turn, adjacent chain-B 1D patterns are further linked into similar 2D (4,4) grid coordination polymer layers by mmmb-B ligands with the Cd⋯Cd through mmmb-B distance of 11.8715(11) Å (Fig. 2). In layer-B, the dihedral angle between the two imidazole rings is 29.3(2)° for the mmmb-B ligands. The apertures bracketed by the oba-B and mmmb-B ligands measure 17.6707(13) by 19.7853(14) Å with Cd⋯Cd⋯Cd angles of 83.41(2)º and 96.59(2)º. Crystallographically distinct layer-A and layer-B motifs then interpenetrate with each other and lead to form an interesting two-fold interpenetrating structure because of the large cage in complex 1 (Fig. 3).

elements.content: The crystal structure of complex 1 is further strengthened through hydrogen bonding interactions between lattice water molecules and carboxylate oxygen atoms (O11⋯O6 = 2.758(4) Å, O12⋯O5 = 2.830(4) Å and O11⋯O3 = 3.294(4) Å), as well as between lattice water molecules (O11⋯O12 = 2.884(6) Å) (Fig. 4). In addition, there are numerous nonclassical C–H⋯O hydrogen bonds in the structure, with C–H⋯O angles in the range 121.4º–171.0º, and C⋯O and H⋯O distances in the ranges 3.117(4)–3.522(4) and 2.37–2.58 Å respectively, generating an extensive three dimensional hydrogen-bond network. This framework is reinforced by π–π interactions between adjacent imidazole rings, with a Cg1⋯Cg2iii separation of 3.616(2) Å [Cg1 and Cg2 are the centroids of the N1–N2/C15–C17 and N5–N6/C42–C44 rings, respectively; symmetry code: (iii) −x + 1, −y + 1, −z + 1], π–π interactions between the benzene rings, with a Cg3⋯Cg3v separation of 3.5366(18) Å [Cg3 is the centroids of the C45–C50 rings, symmetry code: (v) −x + 1, −y + 2, −z + 1] and π–π interactions between the benzene rings, with a Cg4⋯Cg5vi separation of 3.7264(18) Å [Cg4 and Cg5 are the centroids of are the centroids of the C2–C7 and C29–C34 rings; symmetry code: (vi) −x + 1, −y + 1, −z] (Fig. 5). Approximately 5.6 % of the crystal volume is occupied by the solvent molecules, with a volume of 135.7 Å3 in each unit cell (2,419.1 Å3) based on a PLATON calculation.

elements.content: The phase purity of the as-synthesized complex 1 was testified by X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) experiment. The peak positions of the experimental and simulated XRPD patterns are in good agreement with each other, which demonstrates that complex 1 has been obtained successfully as a pure crystalline phase (Fig. 6). The differences in intensity may be owing to the preferred orientation of the powder samples.
elements.clean_text:
PXRD Patterns and Thermal Analysis

The phase purity of the as-synthesized complex 1 was testified by X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) experiment. The peak positions of the experimental and simulated XRPD patterns are in good agreement with each other, which demonstrates that complex 1 has been obtained successfully as a pure crystalline phase (Fig. 6). The differences in intensity may be owing to the preferred orientation of the powder samples.

elements.content: Due to the excellent fluorescent properties of d10 metal complexes, the solid-state photoluminescent property of complex 1 has been investigated at room temperature [18, 19]. The free ligand H2OBA displays photoluminescence with the emission maximum at 319 nm (λex = 276 nm), which are probably attributed to the π*–n or π*–π transitions as previously reported [11]. Irradiation of complex 1 with ultraviolet light (λex = 320 nm) in the solid state resulted in a relatively emission band centered on ~381 nm (Fig. 8). Because the CdII ion is difficult to oxidize or to reduce due to the d10 configuration, the emissions are neither metal-to-ligand charge transfer nor ligand-to-metal charge transfer [20, 21]. As a result, the emissive behavior of complex 1 can be attributed to ligand-centered electronic transitions.
elements.clean_text:
Photoluminescence Properties

Due to the excellent fluorescent properties of d10 metal complexes, the solid-state photoluminescent property of complex 1 has been investigated at room temperature [18, 19]. The free ligand H2OBA displays photoluminescence with the emission maximum at 319 nm (λex = 276 nm), which are probably attributed to the π*-n or π*-π transitions as previously reported [11]. Irradiation of complex 1 with ultraviolet light (λex = 320 nm) in the solid state resulted in a relatively emission band centered on ~381 nm (Fig. 8). Because the CdII ion is difficult to oxidize or to reduce due to the d10 configuration, the emissions are neither metal-to-ligand charge transfer nor ligand-to-metal charge transfer [20, 21]. As a result, the emissive behavior of complex 1 can be attributed to ligand-centered electronic transitions.

elements.content: In summary, one coordination polymer based on mmmb and H2oba has been prepared and characterized through IR, elemental analysis, thermal analysis and single-crystal X-ray diffraction. The crystal structure of complex 1 shows a two-fold interpenetrating (4,4)-connected network. In addition, complex 1 exhibits strong fluorescent emissions in the solid state at room temperature.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, one coordination polymer based on mmmb and H2oba has been prepared and characterized through IR, elemental analysis, thermal analysis and single-crystal X-ray diffraction. The crystal structure of complex 1 shows a two-fold interpenetrating (4,4)-connected network. In addition, complex 1 exhibits strong fluorescent emissions in the solid state at room temperature.

cln_elements.content: A mixture of Cd(NO3)2·6H2O (0.0346 g, 0.100 mmol), H2oba (0.0258 g, 0.100 mmol), mmmb (0.0224 g, 0.100 mmol), NaOH (0.008 g, 0.2 mmol) in H2O (10 mL) was sealed in a 16 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel container and heated at 150 °C for 72 h. After cooling to room temperature, colourless block crystals were collected by filtration and washed by water and ethanol several times (yield 23.2 %, based on Cd). Elemental analysis for C27H22CdN4O6 (Mr = 610.89): C 53.08, H 3.63, N 9.17 %; found: C 53.22, H 3.64, N 9.19 %. IR (KBr, cm−1) 3601 (s), 2375 (w), 1645 (s), 1421 (s), 1123 (m), 981 (m), 742 (m), 652 (s).
cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of the Complex [Cd(oba)(mmmb)⋅H2O]n (1)

A mixture of Cd(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.0346 g, 0.100 mmol), H2oba (0.0258 g, 0.100 mmol), mmmb (0.0224 g, 0.100 mmol), NaOH (0.008 g, 0.2 mmol) in H2O (10 mL) was sealed in a 16 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel container and heated at 150 °C for 72 h. After cooling to room temperature, colourless block crystals were collected by filtration and washed by water and ethanol several times (yield 23.2 %, based on Cd). Elemental analysis for C27H22CdN4O6 (Mr = 610.89): C 53.08, H 3.63, N 9.17 %; found: C 53.22, H 3.64, N 9.19 %. IR (KBr, cm-1) 3601 (s), 2375 (w), 1645 (s), 1421 (s), 1123 (m), 981 (m), 742 (m), 652 (s).

cln_elements.content:
To verify the thermal stability of complex 1, TGA was carried out. As shown in Fig. 7, complex 1 undergoes dehydration in the range of 90–114 °C (obsd. 3.19 %, calcd. 2.95 %), and the decomposition of the organic ligand is observed from 198 to 715 °C. The remaining weight corresponds to the formation of CdO (obsd. 21.86 %, calcd. 21.02 %).

Photoluminescence Properties

Due to the excellent fluorescent properties of d10 metal complexes, the solid-state photoluminescent property of complex 1 has been investigated at room temperature [18, 19]. The free ligand H2OBA displays photoluminescence with the emission maximum at 319 nm (λex = 276 nm), which are probably attributed to the π*–n or π*–π transitions as previously reported [11]. Irradiation of complex 1 with ultraviolet light (λex = 320 nm) in the solid state resulted in a relatively emission band centered on ~381 nm (Fig. 8). Because the CdII ion is difficult to oxidize or to reduce due to the d10 configuration, the emissions are neither metal-to-ligand charge transfer nor ligand-to-metal charge transfer [20, 21]. As a result, the emissive behavior of complex 1 can be attributed to ligand-centered electronic transitions.

Photoluminescence Properties

Due to the excellent fluorescent properties of d10 metal complexes, the solid-state photoluminescent property of complex 1 has been investigated at room temperature [18, 19].
